Welcome to the 2017 edition of The Most Influential People in the North East. 
We have homed in on those individuals who really have the capacity to shape the future of the North East. 
In this section we feature Sarah Stewart, the Chief Executive of NewcastleGateshead Initiative as well as Richard Turner, the Chief Executive of JDR Cables of Hartlepool and Newcastle. 
The entries are not intended to be exhaustive biographies and will not cover all of the person’s roles and responsibilities. Time Line Most Influential 2017 S-T PROFESSOR ROY SANDBACH Director, National Innovation Centre for Ageing, Newcastle 
Hosted by Newcastle University, the National Innovation Centre for Ageing is a Northern Powerhouse initiative. The centre, which was set up by £20m of Government funding, aims to drive the development of innovations to help people live better for longer. Prof Sandbach brings a wealth of global experience to the position, having spent more than 30 years with Procter and Gamble. He is president-elect of the Royal Society of Chemistry Industry Council. Academic links include being a visiting professor at Northumbria, Cranfield and Central St. Martin Universities. Regionally he is an ambassador for NetPark, chairs the North East leadership group of The Prince’s Trust, and is a trustee at the Centre for Life. NEIL SCHNEIDER Chief executive, Stockton-on-Tees Borough Council 
Has held a variety of roles in a local government career spanning 32 years. Neil was appointed as the council’s chief executive in 2008. The authority enjoys high levels of resident, business and employee satisfaction and has been shortlisted for the APSE Council of the Year award for eight consecutive years, winning the honour in 2010. It was one of only six finalists in the ‘Local Authority of the Year’ category at the Municipal Journal (MJ) Achievement Awards 2017 and the only ‘Highly Commended’ entry in its category. Neil is chair of the Tees Valley European Funding Sub-Committee. He also has extensive experience in the development and delivery of leadership training programmes for a wide range of private and public sector organisations. BILL SCOTT Chief executive, Wilton Engineering, Middlesbrough 
Bill has built Wilton Engineering Services from scratch in 1994 to an £85m turnover business providing fabrication and site support to the offshore and petrochemical sectors. In 1999 Universal Coatings was added to the group to support the application of specialist coatings. In October 2015, Wilton and the Nortech Group formed a new collaboration to boost contract wins in a bid to weather the industry slump in the offshore sector. Bill has a passion to support young people through apprenticeships and further education, including degree level, mentoring small to medium enterprises, and is an avid patron of the Middlesbrough and Teesside Philanthropic Foundation and a prolific fundraiser for many good causes. He was The Journal’s Business Executive of the Year 2011, is an EY Entrepreneur of the Year (North of England), IoD Investor Director NE, and North East Business Executive of the Year, not to mention being made an honorary doctor of business administration at Teesside University. JOHN SEAGER Chief executive, Siglion 
Previously with regionally based property company UK Land Estates, John is now the chief executive of Siglion, a joint venture between Carillion Developments and Sunderland City Council, and managed by leading industry experts Igloo Regeneration. Siglion’s mission is to generate economic, social and environmental change in Sunderland through design led development. John is overseeing plans to attract in excess of £100m of private sector investment in regeneration and development projects across key sites to equip Sunderland for rapid, modern economic expansion, including the former Vaux Brewery site in the city centre, at Seaburn and Chapelgarth. ADAM SERFONTEIN Managing director, Hanro Group, Newcastle 
Heads Hanro, one of the region’s largest privately owned property investment companies. Prior to this he spent 12 years with Chesterton Property Consultants, gaining experience across a wide range of markets, working in Newcastle, London, and Madrid. Adam graduated from Northumbria University in 1987, where he is currently deputy chair of the board of governors. In July this year, he received a Doctor of Civil Law honorary degree from Northumbria in recognition of his vast contribution to the region’s economy. He is chairman of Newcastle NE1 Limited, Newcastle’s business improvement district company, a member of the advisory board for InvestNewcastle, which helps businesses to locate, expand and flourish in the city, and chairs Developing Consensus, an alliance of private and public sector organisations, including Northumbria University, that has invested £1bn in the regional economy over that last decade. Adam is also chairman of the Development Board of Marie Curie hospice in Newcastle. BRUCE SHEPHERD 
Working with his late brother Freddy, Bruce has been influential in the development of the north banks of the Tyne since the 1980s, having spotted opportunities in the North Sea oil and gas industry. Shepherd Offshore runs a major facility devoted to housing offshore manufacturing businesses, among them global enterprises such as GE Innovation and the Reece Group. Shepherd Offshore concentrates on property development, provision of warehousing and distribution, quay management and sports management services, and between them the brothers have been instrumental in creating 3,500 jobs on the North Bank of the Tyne. Bruce was awarded an OBE in 2016, and was granted the Freedom of the City of Newcastle earlier this year. LORD SHIPLEY House of Lords, London and Newcastle 
Joined the House of Lords in 2010, the latest staging post in an influential political career which saw him serve on Newcastle City Council for 36 years. He was council leader from 2006 to 2010, and a board member of the former regional development agency One North East. He was the Liberal Democrat Lords principal spokesperson for communities, decentralisation and the Northern powerhouse until the end of 2015, and among posts he currently holds he is vice president of both the Local Government Association, and the National Energy Action Advisory Board. ELLIS SHORT Owner/chairman, Sunderland AFC, Sunderland 
The Missouri-born businessman worked at General Electric before moving into private equity where he made his fortune. He entered the world of football when he bought an initial 30% stake in Sunderland in 2008 as part of the Drumaville consortium. He assumed full control of the club the year after and took over as chairman from Niall Quinn in November 2011. He had been open to selling the club, but Sunderland confirmed in the summer that takeover talks with prospective buyers had ended with the need to rebuild following the Black Cats relegation to the Championship now a more pressing issue. HARI SHUKLA Multicultural ambassador, Newcastle 
The veteran race relations campaigner has fought for racial and religious harmony in Newcastle for 44 years. He takes a keen interest in inter-faith relationships and has worked tirelessly to build bridges between Newcastle’s diverse communities. He has been director of Tyne and Wear Racial Equality, chair of the inter-faith sub-committee of the Tyne and Wear Racial Equality Council, and has also been involved in a number of charities, including the NSPCC and St Oswald’s Hospice, and held dozens of voluntary roles. He has been awarded the OBE, MBE and a CBE, and despite being in his 80s, is still active in the community, being the current vice chair of the North East Council of Faiths. AMANDA SKELTON Chief executive, Redcar and Cleveland Borough Council 
Amanda leads a council that is responsible for delivering services to 135,000 people, with a workforce independent of schools of approximately 2,100, a gross revenue budget of £337m and a five-year capital programme of £85m. She chairs the Government’s SSI Task Force, set up in response to the closure of Redcar’s steel plant in September 2015 which quickly saw all 51 apprentices secured in new positions, more than 1,630 jobs created, and a further 420 safeguarded. More than 300 former workers have now set up their own business. She is also on the board of the newly created South Tees Development Corporation, responsible in part for overseeing the transformation of the SSI site. Amanda is a local ambassador for the Prince’s Trust, and a board member of Safe in Tees Valley. ROSS SMITH Director of Policy, North East England Chamber of Commerce, Durham 
Appointed to his present role in 2012 after working as head of policy and research at the Chamber since May 2007. He is responsible for the Chamber’s relationship with its 3,000-plus members, along with overseeing the organisation’s policy and campaign work, local representation, partnerships and knowledge development. Ross graduated in politics and history from Newcastle University and has worked as a political journalist in Northern Ireland and the North East. Ross is also a school governor. RAY SPENCER Executive director, Customs House, South Shields 
The South Shields Customs House theatre, once described by the Arts Council as “of no regional significance”, has been transformed for the better under Ray’s leadership. He has been chief executive since 2000 and is at the heart of the borough’s cultural life. Despite difficult times in 2015, the Customs House has seen significant growth thanks to the support of customers, sponsors and grant givers. Ray was awarded an MBE in 2010 for services to North East arts and is an honorary fellow of the University of Sunderland. He acts, directs and writes. Having retired his Tommy the Trumpeter role in The Customs House’s annual panto in 2012, he is now a force to be reckoned with as the panto Dame IAN STARK, Chief Executive, Chemoxy International, Middlesbrough 
Chemoxy is one of the region’s largest chemical companies, recording sales of £42m in 2016, and employing over 150 people across its Middlesbrough and Billingham sites. Ian and chief operating officer Martyn Bainbridge acquired Chemoxy in a management buy-out from US-based Dow Chemicals in 2011, creating more than 70 jobs since then and increasing profitability. The firm has recently been sold to French multi-national Novacap SAS for an undisclosed sum, the acquisition seen as an opportunity to further extend Chemoxy’s growing customer base and access to new markets. Ian, who has 35 years experience in the chemical industry, is continuing in his current position. PHIL STEELE General manager, intu Eldon Square, Newcastle 
Phil joined the Newcastle shopping mall in 2010 from Sunderland’s Bridges Shopping Centre where he had spent a decade in charge. He began his career at BHS before moving into shopping centre management at Cameron Toll in Edinburgh. intu Eldon Square, which opened in 1976, has undergone a £230m refurbishment and redevelopment that includes both a new entrance on Northumberland Street as well as a dining quarter that opened in autumn 2016. Twenty new restaurants include a mixture of quality brands alongside several new entrants to Newcastle, such as The Alchemist, Chaophraya, George's Great British Kitchen and Tapas Revolution. The centre hosts 70% of the city’s prime shops among its 120 stores. PETER STEPHENSON Executive chairman, Able UK, Billingham 
Described by a national awards scheme as a “master entrepreneur” Peter is a prominent figure in the Northern business community. Established in 1966 as a specialist in complex demolition processes, Able is now a multi-functional business providing solutions for some of the world’s largest organisations, including decommissioning – the 425-ft tall, 24,000 tonne ‘topside’ of Shell’s Brent Delta oil rig was pulled into Able’s Seaton Carew yard in the summer to be scrapped following the construction of a special £28m quay to host the imposing structure – and as a provider of multi-user port facilities, as well as vehicle storage and distribution. It runs a number of strategic sites covering more than 4,000 acres, including five river frontages on the Tees as well as operations on the Humber. As a privately owned business Able prides itself on taking a long-term view and has invested around £100m over the last seven years GISELLE STEWART Director, UK corporate affairs, Ubisoft, Newcastle 
In her role Giselle is primarily focused on ensuring the optimal environment for both games development and opportunities for Ubisoft's businesses to flourish in the UK. She is passionate about the join-up between education and industry, and sits on the Games Council at Creative Skillset, looking at how match-funding can enable our talent pipeline, and is part of the steering group guiding the NextGen Skills Academy developing trailblazing apprenticeships. Regionally, she is vice chair of Dynamo North East leading its skills agenda, a trustee of North East Futures, the University Technical College due to open in 2018 dedicated to the 'creative, digital and IT' ​(CDIT) and health sciences sectors, and is on the board of the NewcastleGateshead Initiative and Durham University's Department of Computer Science's External Advisory Board. She was awarded an OBE in 2015 for her services to the games industry. SARAH STEWART Chief executive, NewcastleGateshead Initiative, Gateshead 
Sarah has led the team at NewcastleGateshead Initiative since 2010 in its award-winning work to promote the area nationally and internationally to leisure and business visitors and inward investors. During that time she has strengthened the organisation’s mandate, developed new funding streams, and maintained strong private-sector commitment from over 170 partners. A former deputy chair of both the International Centre for Life and Port of Tyne, Sarah continues to hold a number of non-executive positions with Visit England, Arts Council North, Beamish Museum, Newcastle Cathedral, and Newcastle University. She was awarded an OBE in the 2016 New Year’s Honours for services to the North East’s economy. CHRIS STYLES Editor, Gazette Live, Middlesbrough 
Became editor at both the daily title and its website in January 2012, moving from ncjMedia in Newcastle. Chris oversaw the introduction of a digital-first newsroom in May 2014, and www.gazettelive.co.uk become the sixth largest regional newspaper website in Britain, outperforming many large cities, including Leeds, Edinburgh and Glasgow. With an audience increasing at an impressive rate, the Gazette brand is firmly established as the leading and most influential media voice on Teesside. MARTIN SWALES Chief executive, South Tyneside Council, South Shields 
Responsible for an annual budget turnover of £446m and 5,000 staff, Martin has overseen record improvements in schools performance, infrastructure and housing investment and jobs growth. He has placed economic growth and regeneration centre stage, and his work on the A19 economic corridor has supported considerable jobs growth. He continues to oversee the development and implementation of the International Advanced Manufacturing Park in partnership with Sunderland City Council. Regionally, Martin is lead chief executive for Newcastle International Airport and the £8bn Tyne and Wear Pension Fund. Nationally, he is Economic Growth and Housing spokesperson for the Society of Local Authority Chief Executives. HARRY SWAN Managing director, Thomas Swan and Co Ltd, Durham 
Harry is the fourth generation of his family to work at the international chemical manufacturing firm. He graduated from Durham University in 1998 with a degree in plant sciences and began his working life as the scientific affairs manager in the London office of Monsanto Plc. The winner of the prestigious 2017 Carbon Industry Award, which recognises the contribution made by leading industrial scientists and engineers to carbon science and technology, he was Newcastle University Business School’s 2016 David Goldman Visiting Professor for Innovation and Enterprise. Harry is on the board of Innovate UK, which invests more than £500m a year into British innovation, chairman of the Advisory Board of the Centre for Industry Education Collaboration (CIEC), a non-executive director and council member of the UK Chemical Industries Association, and on the Durham Cathedral Investment Committee. RICHARD SWART Global Operation Director, Berger Group, Peterlee 
South African born Richard joined metal ring closure specialist Berger in Peterlee in 1988. The German owned company supplies to the automotive, garden products, filtration, ventilation, ducting, domestic appliance, defence and nuclear waste sectors. Satellite antennae components are also a growth market. Appointed chief executive in 2009, part-relocating to Germany, he returned to the County Durham base in 2012 and spearheaded entry into the lucrative Chinese market. Named in the elite Manufacturer’s Top 100 Report as one of the UK’s most inspiring company leaders, he has supported the global ambitions of hundreds of businesses, and is a committed ambassador for his adopted North East. He is chairman of international trade with the North East England Chamber of Commerce. GEOFF THOMPSON Non-Executive chairman, Utilitywise, North Tyneside 
Geoff stepped down as chairman last autumn in favour of new appointment Brendan Flattery, to become executive chairman, before announcing in April he was to take up a non-executive post as the energy firm strengthens its senior management team as it looks to expand further, especially into the newly deregulated water market. Geoff remains a hugely influential North East business figure, however. He launched Utilitywise 11 years ago with just three employees and has since steered the company to become a major regional player working with around 27,000 small, medium and large businesses, and with overall revenues of £46.1m - up 11% on 2016. A science graduate with an MBA from Newcastle University, Geoff is also chairman of South Shields FC. MARK THOMPSON Managing partner, Ryder Architecture, Newcastle 
Mark has ultimate responsibility for the strategic development of Ryder, which has included broadening the portfolio, adopting new methods of working, and opening offices in Glasgow, Liverpool, London, Vancouver and Hong Kong. Working in the civic, education, healthcare, manufacturing, office, residential, leisure, science and transport sectors, the firm saw turnover grow by 3% to £11.138m in its last financial year. Mark began his career at British Shipbuilders as an engineering apprentice. Following the decline of the industry, he joined Ryder in 1988, qualified as an architectural technician, went on to study project management and business studies at Newcastle University, and became a partner in 1995. He was made an Honorary Fellow of the RIBA in 2003, is on the boards of the North East LEP - where he chairs the group’s Business Growth Board - and NewcastleGateshead Initiative, the chair of blood cancer charity Bright Red, and a member of both the CBI's regional council and national construction council. SANDRA THOMPSON Head Partner, Ernst and Young, Newcastle 
Sandra took over as head partner in July this year, having joined EY in 2016 working out of the firm’s London office as UK audit leader for entrepreneurial and fast growth businesses. Originally from Northumberland, Sandra started work as an apprentice with a small accountancy practice in the North East after leaving school at 16, before moving to Touche Ross (now Deloitte) and being headhunted by PwC. EY has expanded its Newcastle operation in recent years, and now employs more than 500 people, with particular growth in its government and public sector team, financial services advisory practice, and personal tax centre. BRIAN THORPE Head of Business and Corporate Banking, North East, Barclays 
Brian has been responsible for running Barclays commercial banking teams across the North East since 2009, and works with hundreds of businesses in the region who look to what is one of the world’s major financial providers, to help support their future. He has served the banking industry for 36 years covering roles in risk management, retail sales, leadership, and relationship banking, and headed up the UK and European team within Barclays Commercial Bank for the football sector. Brian works hard to ensure clients can develop relationships with key professional bodies and groups, such as the CBI, IoD, North East Entrepreneurs’ Forum, and the North East England Chamber of Commerce, and holds regular networking events. DARREN THWAITES Editor-in-chief, Trinity Mirror North East, Newcastle 
Darren leads the editorial operation of the North East's most influential publishing portfolio. His teams are responsible for the region's two biggest news websites - ChronicleLive and GazetteLive - as well as The Journal, The Chronicle, The Gazette and the Sunday Sun newspapers. In his 12 years as an editor in the region - starting at the Gazette in 2005 - his teams have been industry leaders in the transition to digital publishing. The introduction of a pioneering newsroom model in 2014 delivered explosive audience growth. ChronicleLive and GazetteLive now generate more than 40 million page views and three million video streams a month across desktop, mobile and app. ANNE-MARIE TREVELYAN Conservative MP, Berwick-Upon-Tweed 
Holding onto her Berwick seat with a huge increased majority in the June 2017 General Election, this is Anne-Marie’s second term in Parliament after taking the constituency Tory following the retirement of former Lib Dem incumbent Sir Alan Beith in 2015. She has been a vocal campaigner on a number of issues affecting Northumberland, including the duelling of the A1 - a fight she has pledged to continue - along with getting superfast broadband into all the county’s homes, and helping the UK get a fair Brexit deal. An accountant by training, she has previously sat on Parliament’s influential Public Accounts Committee, and is now the Parliamentary Private Secretary to the MOD ministerial team. FERGUS TRIM Director, Broadoak Asset Management, Newcastle 
Fergus set up Broadoak in 2014, working primarily with New York-based Cerberus Capital Management on various assets, including the 1m sq ft Quorum Business Park in Newcastle and Maxim, a 750,000sq ft office park near Glasgow. Quorum is now one of the most successful business parks in the UK being home to over 25 major businesses including Greggs, Tesco Bank, Balfour Beatty, Fabricom, and British Engines, and supports around 6,000 jobs. It has won numerous accolades, including the Business in the Community award presented by Prince Charles. Fergus is also closely involved in Developing Consensus, the North East property sector member group, and is on the advisory board of Invest Newcastle. ANNA TURLEY Labour MP for Redcar 
Anna held onto the seat she first won in 2015, in this year’s General Election. Before becoming an MP she had worked for more than 10 years as a public servant seeking to tackle social exclusion, poverty and worklessness. Under the last Labour government, Anna was part of the team that brought in the Family Nurse Partnership scheme that supports vulnerable young mums and their children, as well as programmes for adults with severe challenges around substance abuse, homelessness and exclusion. She was a vocal campaigner in the fight to keep Redcar’s SSI steelmaking plant open and campaigns on local issues such as regenerating local high streets, opposing unsustainable housing development, and the need for more local jobs. Until June 2016 she served as the Shadow Minister for the Cabinet Office. PROFESSOR SIR DOUG TURNBULL Professor of Neurology, Newcastle University 
Doug has devoted his career to the treatment and research of devastating mitochondrial disease, for which he has been recognised with a knighthood. He started work in 1976 as a junior doctor, and since then has made the understanding of mitochondrial disease his life’s work, caring for over 1,000 patients and their families, dealing with the effects of a genetic disorder that at its most severe causes blindness, heart failure and ultimately death. His work was acknowledged in 2012 when he and his colleagues were awarded the coveted Wellcome Trust Centre status. Doug has built an internationally renowned team of clinicians and researchers, with patients opting to travel from all over the country to be under his care. PROF JANE TURNER Pro Vice-Chancellor, Teesside University, Middlesbrough 
Jane is responsible for enterprise and business engagement, and is passionate about ensuring Teesside University plays its part in giving its 20,000 students the skills and knowledge the UK’s leaders of the future will need. She came to Teesside in November 2015 from Northumbria University, where she had been the associate dean (business and engagement) in the Faculty of Business and Law. With a doctorate in business leadership, she has a background in human resources and leadership development and worked with the likes of Orange and the Benfield Motor Group, before moving into higher education. She was professor of Enterprise at Northumbria, working in partnership with major employers such as Capita, the NHS, and Proctor and Gamble, and building pioneering degrees in entrepreneurship and corporate management, and bespoke masters’ programmes in leadership and strategy. She is on the board of the new South Tees Development Corporation, whose purpose is to economically regenerate and grow a 5,000 acre site south of the River Tees. RICHARD TURNER Chief Executive, JDR Cables, Hartlepool and Newcastle 
Appointed chief executive in August 2017, Richard joined JDR three years ago to head up the firm’s global manufacturing, project management, and supply chain functions. His promotion follows JDR’s recent acquisition by Polish wire and cable specialists Tele-Fonika. The two companies have a long history of collaboration, and the deal will allow JDR to further ambitious plans for the future, particularly in continuing to provide innovative products and services. Richard has been integral in JDR’s growth, which includes the development of a new wing at its Hartlepool facility to house some of the world’s largest and highest capacity cable and umbilical manufacturing equipment, and the opening of a new site on the Neptune Energy Park in Walker, Newcastle, in the summer. Currently a member of the NOF Energy Board, previously Richard was vice president global manufacturing and planning at Technip/DUCO in Newcastle, where he led the organisation through a period of significant investment and growth. LIZ TWIST Labour MP for Blaydon 
A first time MP, Liz helped Labour retain Blaydon, a seat the party has held since 1935, in June’s General Election. The former regional head of health union, UNISON, she has replaced Dave Anderson, who stepped down for personal and health reasons after 12 years as an MP. A Gateshead councillor for the Ryton Crookhill and Stella ward, Liz worked in Mr Anderson’s constituency office for many years, and is widely known in the borough. Jobs, the NHS, education, housing, the environment, and dignity for people needing care are all important areas for her, and she has pledged to fight for public services. Read More
